attributes.action: Ask HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) management to accept the following minimum working conditions for contact centre and face to face workers: full flexible working hours rights, equal to other staff employed by HMRC, a right to annual leave unless 70% of staff are unavailable that day, to negotiate with the Public and Commercial Services Union for an agreement on working conditions, career development and a strategy to tackle poor staffing levels.
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
Most HMRC Contact Centre workers have worse flexible working hours conditions and more restrictions on how they can take their leave in comparison with other civil servants.

Contact Centre workers within HMRC also face the extremely onerous & draconian management processes in their daily working lives.

Management have refused to negotiate seriously with PCS & contact centre members are monitored for how they use 100% of their time at work and regularly questioned about every minute of every day.

This system of management is causing undue stress within HMRC Contact Centres and PCS stress surveys reflect this.

It is not only the staff however who are suffering under this over bearing system of management but the taxpayer is not being served to an acceptable standard either.

Contact Centre members should be able to take their time to answer a citizens question within their first call & not be under pressure to terminate a call quickly without satisfying the citizens queries.

government_responses.details:
You signed a petition asking the Prime Minister to "Ask HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) management to accept the following minimum working conditions for contact centre and face to face workers: full flexible working hours rights, equal to other staff employed by HMRC, a right to annual leave unless 70% of staff are unavailable that day, to negotiate with the Public and Commercial Services Union for an agreement on working conditions, career development and a strategy to tackle poor staffing levels."

The Prime Minister's Office has responded to that petition and you can view it here: 

http://www.number10.gov.uk/Page19903


Prime Minister's Office
